subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: ... If this would be recommended by the JUnit inventors, they would have added a method like pass() or succeed() in their class TestCase I think. To call a
messageBody:
--- Chris Dollin <kers@...> wrote:
> Neither.
>
> assertTrue(true) looks daft, and the comment won't
> stop style critics.
>
> I have an empty method in my TestBase class(es),
> called `pass`, which
> I call. It expresses intent and shuts up the local
> critic.

If this would be recommended by the JUnit inventors,
they would have added a method like pass() or
succeed() in their class TestCase I think.

To call a method which does nothing, makes no sense in
my eyes. It silences Checkstyle, but is nonsense
nevertheless. Of course methods like pass() or
assertTrue(true) are a kind of documentation. But this
is also a kind of documentation, and can be used
everywhere, not just for a test:

try
{
...
}
catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
{
// Ignore
}
